Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Igor Klebanov, Alexander Polyakov, and Herman Verlinde at Princeton University.

As part of this project, Professors Klebanov, Polyakov, and Verlinde will carry out a broad program of research in theoretical and mathematical physics, with the goal of extending advances in the foundational aspects of quantum field theory and the Einstein theory of gravity. These researchers also intend to apply these advances to the physics of the Universe, to quantum black holes, to particle physics beyond the Standard Model, and to condensed-matter physics. An important aspect of this research program concerns the precise relations between quantum gauge field theories and gravitational theories, known as gauge/gravity dualities. Also included in these studies are gravitational theories that contain fields of arbitrarily high spin.

This research project is also envisioned to have an essential educational and mentoring component: preparing post-docs, graduate students, and advanced undergraduates for successful research careers. Some of these students and post-docs go on to become leaders in theoretical physics, while others embark on successful careers in biophysics, neuroscience and other sciences. In all cases, the education, research supervision and mentoring they receive provides a broad impact that transcends the immediate research results. The physicists supported by this award will also continue to be active in organizing advanced schools, workshops and conferences. They have also organized and presented public lectures, informing broader audiences about recent research developments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research funded under this grant has contributed to progress on a fundamental problem in physics: how to merge Einstein's theory of gravity with the known fact that the microscopic world is described by quantum mechanics. Einstein's theory predicted that the most compact possible objects are the black holes, whose gravity is so strong that even the light cannot escape. The understanding of Einstein's theory of gravity at the quantum mechanical level has evaded a complete solution for many years, but an important step, to which the Princeton University researchers made many original contributions, took place in the relatively recent history. It was discovered that certain quantum theories of gravity may be described by the more conventional quantum mechanical systems. This “holographic” identification has already provided valuable information about the quantum behavior of black holes, but the problem is still far from being solved completely. Recent research has modeled a description of certain simplified models of black holes by quantum mechanical systems with a large number of degrees of freedom, and research funded under this grant contributed to this progress. In particular, certain simplified effective actions coupled to other degrees of freedom were derived and shown to play an important role. The chaotic behavior which is often exhibited by quantum mechanical systems was related to the physics of black holes.

The conjectured dual relations between quantum gravity and quantum models without gravity sometimes involve an infinite tower of higher spin degrees of freedom which interact with gravity. The leading quantum corrections in such higher-spin models were calculated and shown to support the earlier conjectures.

The research has also advanced our understanding of the nature of transitions that occur in the behavior of matter when certain parameters like the temperature and pressure are varied. In particular, the scaling exponents governing certain second order phase transitions were understood better than before. The theory at such a transition point typically exhibits the conformal symmetry, which generalizes symmetry under scaling up all distances. The quantum field theories, i.e. theories with infinite numbers of quantum degrees of freedom, which exhibit such conformal symmetry were explored actively. Some quantum field theories have been previously argued to exhibit other emergent symmetries, in particular, the boson-fermion symmetry called supersymmetry, and the research under the grant provided convincing evidence that this is the case. The fascinating issues related to quantum entanglement in systems with an infinite number of degrees of freedom were explored at a deep and quantitative level.
